title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" amends Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new subchapter for screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury. The Act "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" establishes a screening program for veterans eligible for care to screen for traumatic brain injury symptoms. The Secretary must submit an annual report on the number of veterans screened, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for care improvement. Additionally, a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation will be developed and implemented. The Act "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" establishes a screening program for eligible veterans to screen for traumatic brain injury symptoms. A comprehensive long-term care program for post-acute traumatic brain injury rehabilitation will be implemented at four designated polytrauma network sites for veterans meeting specific eligibility criteria. The Act establishes traumatic brain injury transition offices at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress on the program's operation, number of veterans served, and annual costs. The Act establishes a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry for veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom with symptoms of traumatic brain injury. It includes their names and relevant medical data for care and compensation purposes. The Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry includes relevant medical data and information for individuals granting permission or deceased. The Secretary notifies individuals listed in the Registry of significant research developments on the health consequences of military service in Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom theaters of operations. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, includes provisions for screening, comprehensive rehabilitation programs, transition offices, and a registry for traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
